_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.1	SOURCE AND PROCESS DESCRIPTION
1.2	SOURCE
The Rust-Oleum Corporation (Rust-Oleum) Distribution Center located in Riverside, California, is subject to the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPAs) Risk Management Program (RMP) for Accidental Chemical Release regulation (40 CFR 68) because it contains a mixture of propane (Chemical Abstract System [CAS] number 74-98-6) and n-butane (CAS number 106-97-8) exceeding 10,000 pounds. The mixture is used as a propellant for aerosol paint cans.
Finished goods are transferred to the warehouse for storage and distribution. Mixtures of propellant, flammable liquids, and paint solids are stored in 12- or 18-ounce cans. Approximately 240,000 pounds of propellant may be stored in the well protected warehouse at any one time.
Propellant is a flammable and potentially explosive gas. The propellant is not inherently toxic.
2.1	POTENTIAL RELEASE SCENARIO
2.2	WORST-CASE SCENARIO
Consistent with the RMP rule requirements, a worst-case release from the largest single container was analyzed to assess the maximum distance to the flammable endpoint. This facility only stores 12- and 17- ounce cans of finished goods and has no associated process piping or vessels, therefore the worst-case and alternate-case release scenarios would be the same. The release scenarios analyzed and the endpoints evaluated are based on the guidance contained in the USEPAs off site Consequence Analysis Guidance.
3.0	ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of propellant at the Rust-Oleum, Riverside, California warehouse in the last 5 years that have resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site; or off-site death, injury, property damage, evacuation, sheltering in place, or environmental damage.
4.0	PREVENTION PROGRAM
Although a formal, documented prevention program is not required by the RMP rule for Program 1 processes, a number of design and operational controls are in place to decrease the severit

y or prevent the occurrence of a fire or explosion. The most significant controls are described below:

The warehouse is designed as an aerosol warehouse in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)   Manufacture and Storage of Aerosol Products code (NFPA 30B).

All electrical equipment meets the requirements of the National Electric Code (NFPA 70).
5.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Rust-Oleum, Riverside facility has implemented a detailed written Emergency Response Plan (ERP). The ERP is intended to address all emergencies at the facility, including incidents related to a release of propellant.

The ERP includes coordination with the local fire department, and evacuation of personnel in the facility. The ERP identifies specific individuals and their responsibilities, and identifies procedures for emergency medical care.
